ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: conceptual debate about racism, the stakes of defining racism, the historical roots of racism, how to diagnose racism, how to respond to racist things

Survey knowledge of a variety of interdisciplinary investigations into racism; a LOT of relevant history--not necessarily in depth, but certainly in scope--to racism in the US today; how to write a personal definition/theory of racism; a more complicated understanding of the nature of discrimination in the US.

This class is an in-depth look into the definition of racism and the application of these definitions. Though it isn't a strength or a weakness, it is worth noting that much of this class is a little abstract.
Developed deep critical thinking skills, specifically in the context of racism and racist structures.
A toolkit for the discussion and analysis of racism and its effects.
I learned about theories of how racism operates, racism across domains and levels, and social science approaches to studying racism
I gained the analytical and theoretical skills necessary to do a broad diagnosis and demonstration of racism in different domains and at different levels

I LEARNED A LOT AND THIS YEAR HAS BEEN TRASH BUT the class really forces you to think critically, and my main takeaways were that racism does not have to be intentional, it cannot be separated from history, and intersectionality is often key to understanding racism. i had to really dig deep into research for those papers and also be okay with spending weeks writing a paper.

Understanding the nuances of the definitions of racism, but also how to understand, talk about, and critique the multidimensionality of any socio-political, historical issue. Honestly, it's a class in understanding how the world works.

I gained a much better understanding of racism through many lenses including how to diagnose racism in different contexts and how to create theories and definitions of racism. I learned about how to pick apart other theories of racism to find what they do not cover.
The theory behind racism and the quantitative social science methods which can be used to detect it in real-life scenarios
I learned how to approach the diagnosis of racism with care and patience.
A stronger sense of methodology in social science of racism. Helpful introduction to principles for making social scientifically rigorous claims to causality and impact.

I learned about many different perspectives about approaching and figuring what is and what is not racist. This class helped me develop a much more applicable definition of racism for many more situations. Overall you learn so much about others and yourself and how many things around us are very much racist.
the ability to develop theories of racism, a good foundation of important history relevant to defining racism, ability to look critically at different people or things and their capacity for racism

I learned how to form my own definition and theory of racism and how to apply it in the real world. I also learned to consider what the stakes are of calling something racist, who benefits and who suffers from a given definition, and how racism operates on different levels across different domains.
I learned how to take a closer look into complex issues to ascertain driving forces towards their conception.
Theories of Racism (Hall, Black Feminist Theory, etc) and methods to quantify discrimination (Statistics)
Through this course, I was able to learn the importance of asking questions about our definitions of racism and possible solutions we come up with to address it.
Goff was stellar.
defining racism using statistical and social science means.
how to take experiences and engage with them academically

We developed a vocabulary for defining racism and identifying what is/isn't racist. We read from a variety of texts, with a focus on sociological studies and methodologies, to supplement our own understanding of racism. The papers assigned to us were especially insightful, as they forced us to apply the readings to subject matters that have stakes, both personal and societal.
I learned how to apply a critical/theoretical lens to instances of racism.
i learned how to question my previous beliefs and how to analyze concealed structural racism in more in-depth ways.

I learned how to critically evaluate statistical evidence, how much context matters to the arguments we make, how to deal with common objections against racism and most importantly, we were constantly pushed to forge our opinions on these very important topics regarding race
I learned that defining terms and stakes is vital to have a productive discussion. I also learned that how we define terms can have a last single impact on various levels and among different groups.
This course improved my ability to read scientific and academic literature and think critically about questions of race and racism.
A great introduction into thinking about ways to define and measure racism and its impacts.

I learned about racism in-depth: how it operates at different levels, the intersection of it and other forms of discrimination, how to use quantitative measures to demonstrate it.  I learned how to define it and defend our definition in the first half of the class and how to use that definition to address racism in societies.
I learned how to analyze data and readings in a way that challenged white supramacy.
How to diagnose racism. How to conduct research and write an argumentative paper. How to think critically about research conducted on the subject of racism.
Adequate vocabulary to articulate some strong feelings about race and class, and some proper readings to feel secure in your understanding of historical and current phenomena of racial strife
My reading and writing skills have improved.
I learned effective strategies to identify and diagnose racism, and what implications arise from different diagnoses.

I learned an incredibly important amount about the history and continuance of racism in the United States that truly changed my perspective on the world. This class improved my skills in identifying and diagnosing racism around me which has helped me to become a better person in my personal life and in relationships.
allowed me to properly articulate my thoughts about something that effects my everyday life

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: professor is incredible, lectures were engaging, humorous where appropriate, and very insightful. 

weakness: discussions sections were challenging because the topics were so heavy and often uncomfortable to discuss.

Strengths: Dr. Goff has an incredible lecture presence, appropriately comedic, thoughtful, and compassionate when addressing the subject matter. A lot of thought clearly went into the construction of the class. The 2 big assignments of this course, the midterm and final, are challenging, but really allow you to bring in the cumulative knowledge of the semester and grow through the work.
Weaknesses: Sometimes sections could meander a bit, and keeping up with the readings (especially during the period before the final is due) can be a real challenge. Similarly, the midterm spills into the final, which can be tough to keep up with--both require a lot of deep thinking!
The weekly discussion board posts were a bit laborious at times, and the paper assignments were a little strange. However, these also seemed to be helpful in my digestion of the material.

Strengths: Professor Goff, well-paced readings, important and interesting content.
Weaknesses: Professor Goff has so much knowledge to share, and too little time to share it! I left most lectures wondering how the time went by so fast, especially over zoom.
The readings and lectures were very interesting and engaging.

strengths: Professor Goff is an incredible lecturer and so passionate; manageable workload; interesting topic and readings
weaknesses: none

Strengths- very organized, good TA, good instructor, good content, allows for individualized exploration of topic since you can take the 2 papers in whatever direction you'd like, Dr. Goff makes the lessons v relevant to ongoing current events etc (obviously this is expected with the relevance of the content covered but i appreciate the intentionality). 
Weaknesses- It would have been nice if the assessments for this class weren't 2 very strictly academic formatted assignments. It could be cool to have some sort of creative choice/ project-based assessment (with potential collaboration) like other AFAM and ER&M courses

PROF GOFF AND our TA daniella are amazing, phenomenal people. prof goff is 100% a strength in this class. he genuinely cares so much about students and can be like hey yall this is a tough time and i get that and it doesn't feel fake. his teaching is engaging, and it's so obvious that this is something he cares deeply about and that his words are backed by action. the weakness of the course is perhaps not a weakness but moreso that THAT MIDTERM PAPER AND FINAL PAPER HIT DIFFERENT. you do the readings that are pretty long but eventually figure out how to do them more efficiently or skim and read what's important but then THE PAPERS. you spend weeks writing and researching and rewriting and realizing prof goff wants something different and then APA CITATIONS ARE HELL. if you want the learning without the pain, credit D it. but also talk to your TA, start early, and do it (but also for students of color, writing about racism can be traumatic and painful. doing research for my final paper i did break down crying multiple times, so be aware of how certain topics might impact your mental health)
It's just the best, it's really incredible.

Professor Goff is the biggest strength of this course. He is a genuine, intelligent, and compassionate professor. I appreciate the way that the lectures were laid out clearly and expressed specifically what we would cover.
Professor Goff was an engaging lecturer and the TFs were very organized and knowledgable. The material was not too dense and clearly relevant. However, I did not particularly enjoy the assignments.

Strengths: Professor Goff! Hes engaging, incredibly knowledgeable, and just amazing. My TF was very understanding and approachable as well. We learned so much in that class, but it always felt interesting. The papers felt incredibly rewarding to finish.

Strengths: Dr. Goff is super knowledgable and a compelling lecturer, and the readings were a good length and variety to engage me without being punishing. 
Weaknesses: Did not feel actually that rigorous an analysis of racism from any angle other than psychology/social science, which could make it feel hard to focus on systems and legacies of power, though Dr. Goff made a concerted effort to mention these factors. Also did not feel particularly supported by teachers.
The discussion sections were amazing with the diverse amount of insight from all of the participants.

Strengths: GREAT lectures and GREAT professor; content was very interesting and discussion section was always engaging; readings were manageable and interesting

Weaknesses: lectures were sometimes fast-paced (the professor addressed this problem towards the end of the semester after receiving feedback); I sometimes felt lost in the material i.e. lectures were at times confusing; I felt like at times I left the lecture with more questions than answers (although this may be the nature of this class)

This course was amazing. I learned that we cannot just call everything we see racist. Racism is such a strong word and the definition that we use to define it must encapsulate the elements of history and power. This course taught me that there isn't just one definition of racism. Take this course and educate yourself. Professor Goff is amazing.

Strength - professor 
Weakness - still dont know what racism is.
The course had an amazing professor and a very interesting and important subject matter. It could be improved by having more structured section.

Professor Goff is a great lecturer and the point of the course -- to help us develop our own definitions of racism based on others' and to use that insight to identify what is/isn't racist -- is in itself a strength. I found myself devoting extra time to the work for this class because I genuinely cared. One thing I wished we had more of was feedback. It is always difficult to get constant feedback in a (Zoom) lecture-format class, but getting more direct feedback would have been greatly appreciated. Often times, feedback could have been vague due to the nature of the course and TAs having to read several papers and proposals; however, I wish I could have gotten comments more specific to my interests throughout the course.

Strengths: Dr. Goff was very engaging during lecture and I learned so much from him. I always enjoyed lectures with him. I also think sections were very helpful and fun times for learning. Weaknesses: Though I enjoyed reading the theory for this class, it felt very hand-hold-y. I think this course was geared more towards white people than anyone else--which is fine, but I just wish that had been made clear at the start. I've taken plenty of other ER&M classes that go into way more depth than this class. If you've taken a few ER&M classes, a lot of the readings will be familiar.

this course was very strong. it was organized perfectly to support student understanding of all assignments and deadlines & etc. were very considerate being that we are in a pandemic and many students were off-campus. the course was also well organized in terms of academic structure. it was very inclusive as well. i felt very welcome in the class even when talking about sensitive subjects.
I like how interdisciplinary the course is, however, I wonder if having some sort of equal experience in statistics or some race theories can make the discussions we had in seminars better

Honestly, I cannot think of any weaknesses. The lectures were incredible and felt like mini Ted talks each time. Dr. Goff opens each one playing music and did an amazing job encouraging student participation, which fostered a sense of community in the class even though it was a lecture. The TFs were brilliant and so helpful in deciphering and further discussing lecture material in section. I also really appreciated that Dr. Goff always held space during class for what was happening in the news and how  it both related to the class and affected students' wellbeing.

Strengths: the course does very well in laying out why it is important to define stakes and have a definition. 

Weaknesses: the course is laid out so that the first half of the semester covers theory while the second covers more methods of measuring it analysis of racism. I wish more time was spent discussing the theory as it was harder to grasp. I also wished I received more feedback.
A strength of this course is the discussion sections as they allowed us to discuss the readings in a smaller group format.

This class was really great by far the best class I've taken this year. The strengths of the course can, in large part, be attributed to Dr. Goff. He is incredibly passionate about the course material, and that really comes through clearly in an inspiring and interesting way. The lectures were engaging and interesting, and the readings were well and obviously carefully chosen. This is the first class at Yale for which I have actually read everything assigned, both because it was a reasonable amount and because they were all truly interesting and added something to the course.

Strengths:  The content was great and I felt like I was genuinely learning something new every week. Prof. Goff is a phenomenal lecturer and really cares about students and our struggles.  He and the TFs were very accommodating during this difficult semester.  They were very helpful in preparing for the midterm and final papers: they offered plenty of advice and opportunity during lecture and section to discuss and develop ideas. 

Weaknesses & Improvements: Going over the weekly summaries took up a lot of time during section.  If we got the summaries with the TF addendums the morning of section, were able to review it beforehand, and just jump into discussion questions that would have been great.  Sometimes the readings were a lot during the week leading up to papers being due.  If we had no readings or shorter readings those weeks, that would be great.  Otherwise, pretty good.

The class was very engaging, and the course material was relevant and interesting. Near the beginning of the semester, we went through some of the topics quicker than I would've liked. It was also difficult to get in touch with the professor due to his busy schedule.

I really wish I could retake this class in person, but the lectures were amazing nonetheless. I think I learned more from this class than I learned from any other class at yale so far and enjoyed the learning along the way.
strengths: interesting, interactive

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
succeeded: engaging lectures, using the chat function

improved: discussion section engagement

Succeeded: Lecture recordings. It was monumentously helpful to be able to go back and revisit earlier material with more context and more time to process. Especially because Dr. Goff can sometimes move a little quickly (and many of the concepts require deeper engagement.)

Could be improved: It might have helped to have a section icebreaker or similar exercise at the beginning of the semester. I'm not sure if it was Zoom or difficulty in talking about the material with strangers, but the first few weeks of section felt a little stiff--it took a while for people to warm up and grow more comfortable actually discussing things.

Everything went pretty well. Our discussion section took a few sessions to warm up to each other, which may have been easier in person, but Professor Goff and the teaching team did an excellent job with the constraints Zoom placed on us.
Despite the fact that it was a large lecture, we used the chat function on Zoom to stay engaged during the lecture

Dr. Goff and my TA always made sure to prioritize our mental and physical health over anything and they made sure to let us know-- my TA was very understanding with being flexible on assignment due dates etc

the zoom chat engagement that prof goff managaed to achieve was phenomenal, discussions felt too short but generally alright (would have loved more time talking about papers though), and just prof goff's teaching. amazing. memorable. forced us to think critically while providing us the tools to
The chat!! When it wasn't being misused, getting immediate class feedback and answers and ideas was incredibly helpful.
The combination of lecture and sections.
I typically find live virtual lectures rather unenjoyable, but this one was able to function over Zoom quite well. Professor Goff really made use of the Zoom chat function.

I appreciated that every lecture was recorded. However, I would have benefited from having a copy of the slides/notes in advance to pay more attention to what the professor was saying rather than focusing too much on writing notes.
All of the readings were online, which was super helpful! I also liked how all of the lectures were recorded. I think this course worked well online.

this course was very strong. it was organized perfectly to support student understanding of all assignments and deadlines & etc. were very considerate being that we are in a pandemic and many students were off-campus.
This classes did well in being geared towards learning by including closed captions and being recorded.
Allowing students to interact with the content and each other in the chat during the lecture.  Having closed captions during lecture.  Recording lecture for later reference.
The lecture was super engaging.
I think the information taught in class was still engaging despite being virtual.
Again I wish I could have taken this class in person, but the COVID accommodations were great.
more office hours

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes. I think it is clear in the name, this is a course everyone needs to take. professor goff is incredible.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student!  In terms of classes that will actually develop and deepen your understanding of the world around you, challenge you, and improve you as a person, this is it. Regardless of major or intended field of study, this is a class that matters.
Absolutely. This class (or a class like it) should be a requirement.
Absolutely! A must take, I think. Challenging work that matters.
Yes. As a graduating senior, this is, without a doubt, the best course I have taken at Yale. Professor Goff is the best lecturer I have ever seen. The whole team put so much work into every detail.
YES! It is such an important topic, regardless of major.
Yes!
Yes!

I would recommend this course to a student who is willing to be challenged with the assignments. Both the midterm and final paper required students to think very critically. This is not a gut or a 5th credit type of class.

if you don't have the time, make the time and take this course. it's not easy, but also the main bulk of work is those papers. the class created nuanced conversations and questions that oftentimes showed the grey areas in different topics while also being sensitive about how race can be a challenging topic  . and if anything was hurtful for students, prof goff genuinely cares about that and takes feedback and makes efforts to make it the best possible experience for students. i actually wanted to go to lectures which during zoom university is saying something
YES 100% YES
YES. This course is absolutely incredible. I learned so much. I engaged with difficult material in an insightful and meaningful way.
This was not a life-changing course, but if you are passionate about the topic then you will enjoy it.
I would definitely recommend this class!!

I would recommend this course if you are interested in Dr. Goff's work and approach, or if you are a psych/socsci student who is interested in applying your methodologies to racial issues. It's a bit far-ranging but strongly connected by certain methodological approaches and themes. Certain parts of the course were a bit uninteresting to me as an ER&M major who has engaged with race regularly in college classes, but could be a helpful introduction for people who don't have as much experience and want to learn more
Yes because racism has become a more important topic in today's world and the realizations that you come across are so mind boggling and interesting. Overall amazing course and topic to learn about.

YES!! This class is useful and necessary for people of all majors, especially since racism is so embedded in our systems and structures. This class will help you put into words the definition of racism, which will then help you recognize how prevalent it is in society. This class was SO informative and engaging. The professor is also extremely knowledgeable and will push you to your limit (in a good way!). He will force you to ask yourself important questions and truly reflect on the material. This class teaches you important skills that are not just applicable to the topic of racism; it will teach you that you need to form a definition of the problem and your solution will be dependent on your definition. Overall, this was a truly rewarding class.
yeah it's a good intro to a broad topic
Definitely! There was a lot of information presented that was useful, relevant, and insightful that would help those who knew it.
I would definitely recommend this course to a student. The workload is not too much (2 critical questions per week, 2 essays) but you learn so much from Professor Goff in the lectures.
Yes--especially in the current political climate that exists, we should all be educating ourselves about diagnosing and dealing with racism.
Absolutely. A must for any Yalie.

Absolutely, Professor Goff was fantastic and every lecture was super engaging. The assignments were definitely challenging but worthwhile. With only two papers and weekly reading responses, the workload is not bad.
yes!!!
I would if you have absolutely no experience in talking about racism and if you need a theoretical basis to ground yourself. Otherwise, I don't think you're missing much.

I would reccommend this course to every student. As a black student, I feel that this course was one of the most real, most equitable, fair, honest, and inclusive classes on racism that I have ever taken.
Definitely! Every lecture we learned so much about the social world around us and we were equipped with the tools and language to explain our frustrations in the world.

Absolutely, you should take this course. This was one of the best classes Ive ever taken. Take it for the lectures - concise but full of so much fascinating and incredibly relevant material. Take it for the content so that you can spend a semester learning and tailoring the arguments youve always wanted to make about where racism arises and the evidence to back claims up. Take it for Dr. Goff, who is one of the best lecturers out there - sarcastic, funny, and inspirational. He really cares about how students are doing and wants to help them succeed in the class papers and also in life.

I would only recommend this class to students who will be engaged in this course and actually take time to think/discuss about lecture and reading materials. This is especially true for the two big papers in the class. You learn the most by doing those two papers.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. This was my favorite course this semester because I found the lectures and readings very interesting and the discussions were engaging.
Absolutely. I really loved this course, and would recommend it to anyone.
YES! this course is incredible and so is Prof. Goff

YES YES YES! I highly recommend this class because the topic is very important and the way it is explored is great: the readings are fascinating, and section discussions are lively.  It is a very organized class and there is never a dull moment.  It is one of the best courses I've taken so far and I think everyone should take it during their time at Yale.
Yes absolutely!

If you're ready to seriously engage with your readings, coursework, and lecture, then yeah, go for it. One of the classes that actually challenges you. It is very TA dependent though. Sometimes the grading is arbitrary, and there is no transparency. It's a tough course, I won't lie. This class seems more than just an intro course, so don't let the low number fool you.

If you are anywhere to the left of Pete Buttigieg, then the intellectual challenge of this class is basically nonexistent. I noticed that some people had a harder time wrapping their heads around systemic racism than others, and that's okay! If that classification doesn't apply to you, then the onus of learning has to be on you on what you want to get out of this class. Luckily, most if not all of the TAs are helpful about that and will help you get where you need to be. I personally had a good time in the class, even if the main lecture was less than stimulating.
Yes, the class was engaging and the TF was super supportive.
I would recommend the class, because I think that everything I learned can be applied to my life going forward, no matter the subject I choose to major in.

Yes, the class is very informative and the conversations that developed in discussion section were very interesting. This course covers important issues and definitions, so I would definitely recommend
Absolutely take this course! Prof Goff is amazing and you will learn so much.
YES -- this is by far the best class I have ever taken at Yale, and Dr. Goff is absolutely wonderful. Do not graduate without taking this class!!!
absolutely

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: lectures were also recorded. and weekly virtual discussion sections.
Lectures were also recorded.
+ Discussion Sections
section
live virtual lecture and discussion section
Combination of live virtual lectures and recorded lectures
live lecture or recorded and virtual seminar discussion
Virtual live lecture + virtual live discussion section.
Included a virtual discussion section
There was a live virtual discussion section as well which really helped with the comprehension of the readings.
Live virtual lecture
There were also sections
Recorded Lecture and Live Virtual Lecture
virtual discussion section
Discussion section
Apart from the recorded lecture, we also engaged in discussion sections on a weekly basis.
weekly section
Virtual weekly section
live virtual section every week
None
Live virtual discussion section
Live virtual lecture that was recorded and discussion sections were live virtual.
The course included live virtual lectures and virtual discussion sections.
Live virtual lecture with recordings posted and also weekly discussion section live with TF
Live Lecture that was recorded, live non-recorded section
sections were zoom seminars
We also had small sections once a week.
The recordings were a great resource to come back to throughout the semester
Discussion sections!
recorded lecture
